posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

Get a haircut every 2 months. If you are balding just cut'em short, anything else looks shit and insecure about it.
If your clothes are ripped, stretched and discolored as shit, get some new ones. Basic, monotone, cheap shirts will do just fine. Again, depending on your sweat wear'em between 1 and 3 days, then change. If you got a pile of dirty rags wash it.

This brings us to your home. Doesn't matter if you live alone or with your parents, clean your dwelling once a week. Empty bottles and packages are to be thrown away immediately, instead of hoarded. It's no work if you do it this way. Used plates, glasses, etc., are to be washed off immediately after use. Again, if you do it like this, it's way less work than cleaning off a whole pile of them.
Changing bed sheets and vacuuming the place once a week.

A healthy mind lives in a clean body, living in a clean place. All that grime on yourself and around you poisons your mind. This regime gets rid of that without too much effort. You will also feel a sense of accomplishment, which boosts you for what comes next, LEAVING THE HOUSE

STEP #2, LEAVE HOUSE:
Go out every day. Do long walks of atleast 2 hours. Explore your city, your surroundings. Go into alleys you never walked before. Whenever you think, oh whats there or I never was there or anything similiat, thats where you go!
Do not ask yourself shit, like "whats the use? Enjoy the moment, do not drown out your surrounsings with your depressive thoughts.

APAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
STEP #3, SOCIALIZE:
I want you to greet people on your walks. Not some barely audible mumble, but a clear greeting. Establish eye contact, throw'em a good day coupled with a nod or a quick wave. I want your face to glow and your voice to echoe joy when you do this. Doesnt matter if its forced and unnatural at first, its training, if it came natural to you we wouldn't have to have this conversation.

After a few weeks or months of doing everything I told you, you should feel better about yourself. You wont be chad, fucking bitches left and right and going through life constantly happy, but at leaat you wont feel absolutely miserable for once. You may be able to pull off more intense forms of socializing now.

Get into the habit of doing smalltalk with strangers, like cashiers or the people you meet on walks. It doesn't matter that it's benign and trivial shit, just do it. Observe them, what they wear, their hair, makeup, tatoos, whatever and throw them a compliment, ask them where they got it from, what meaning it holds to them. When the convo naturally found its end, say your goodbye and go on your way.

STEP #4, GET A REAL HOBBY:
You should be prepared now, physically and mentally, to go out there and take the risk of trying new stuff, which will include meeting people doing the same stuff, but you are ready for that.

Here are things I can vouche for: Bouldering/climbing, martial arts, swimming, biking, skating, going to a chess/go/shogi/mahjong/etc center where you can watch, learn and play. If you like reading, go to a library instead of doing it at home. Generally, I advise you to engage mind and body. Try several physical activities and intellectual/creative ones.

At this point it should become a self perpetuating cycle. Keep challenging yourself, keep experiencing,exploring and learning new things.
Learn to "live in the moment". Dont question the use or meaning, do not rationalize, try to let the stimuli wash over you like a river.

APAP

Is it necessary for there to be a definition of bad when everyone has their own competing perspective? Or are we, dare I say it, Beyond Good & Evil?

This kind of moral subjectivity has such far reaching implications that I'm having trouble even starting a thought about it. From existentialism, non-aggression, gnosticism, LIBERTARIANISM,

There's nothing really 'bad' objectively, only bad subjectively.

Think about subjectivity and perspective here. There's one slice of pizza left and we both want it. We can't split it or save it. I want it, if I get it, that's good. But to you, subjectively, the opposite is true.

Can't each person have their own subjective values? Even a pair of identical twins develop distinction through their individual experiences. It's completely possible for two conflicting opinions to be equally right and good and bad and wrong at the same time

>>71916298
it's the smallest number that can be expressed as the sum of two cubes two different ways!
1729 = 1^3 + 12^3 = 9^3 + 10^3
there's a story where british mathematician Hardy visits another mathematician Ramanujan in a hospital, and points this number out on the back of a passing taxi as being somewhat uninteresting and maybe a bad sign. Ramanujan quickly responds by saying the number is in fact very interesting for the reason above, so it's sometimes called the Taxicab number after the anecdote

>>71916399
its not that surprising since it's just euler's formula.

>>71916399
that's a lovely one. contains all the most important constants we have!
you may be familiar with this already, but for a little extra intuition about this equation you can think about any instance of e^(i*x) as being some kind of rotation in the complex plane. to see why this is, consider the taylor expansion of e^(x) and then try substituting in i to find the expansion for e^(ix). notice that after factoring out the terms with i left over you'll be left with the taylor expansion for cos(x) + i*sin(x), which should resemble a unit circle somewhat :)
now consider that a rotation of 180 degrees is the same as rotating pi radians, and since we start from 1+0i, we'll find that rotating by pi radians as e^(i*pi) should give us -1+0i. Now we add one and find that e^(i*pi)+1=0+0i=0 ^^

posts.sub: This story might sound 100% made up, but it's true. These are just the highlights
posts.com:
So, a few years ago, I was living in a sharehouse. There were 4 of us living there. 2 normies, a weirdo, and myself.

The weirdo kinda just seemed to be a well-meaning autist. Very good with computers, a bit of a slob, and had no social skills. He was fun to be around.

At some point, he bought a projector. We used it to play vidya on an entire wall. Good times.

Now, despite him being otherwise quite smart, he couldn't read. At some point, someone gave him an illustrated history book.

He spent a lot of time looking at ancient Egyptians and Buddhists and put that autist brain into making connections. He'd got it into his head that the Egyptians built the pyramids with powers they'd gotten from the sun.

He did try to tell me that by staring into the sun, you could gain these same powers and that he'd been doing it for weeks. This will come up later.

A few months later, he'd changed his mind. He now believed the Buddha and the Egyptians had channelled power through pinecones. Source: Buddha has a pinecone on his head. At this point, I sorta stopped hanging out with him.

This is just your basic crazy. Trust me, it gets better.

I think something might have broken in him at some point, but he reported hearing the voice of God, telling him that he was Jesus. He wouldn't shut the fuck up about it.

I'm not sure why God told him to, but he had to spend 40 days and 40 nights in the rainforest.

He came back after 5, reporting that he ate a poisonous mushroom because God told him to and that he had spent 3 days in agony, sweating and vomiting while being eaten alive by mosquitos.

After this, he was convinced that he could see and control the "energies" in the world and that he had the power of telekinesis. Conveniently, he always failed to prove it. I believe he had burned a hole in his retinas by staring at the sun, and his terrible vision was the "energy."

More in comments

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I left not long after, but I heard from my housemates that he'd disappeared. I shit you not

His room was empty of all belongings. The floor was covered in feathers, and the walls were lined with rocks and 100+ pinecones.

Housemates sent me a video, which unfortunately I can't find (this happened about a year ago), but it looked something like picrel

>>71911246
>It really is, and it's especially noticeable if you look into its Psychological Types roots. "Preferential movements of the libido ['psychic energy,' lol]," as written in there.
Indeed, it's what most of the complete book deals with, and ends up being the main point of confusion for people.

I think it helps to understand Jung's reason for elaborating his theory too. He was trying to give a different view from Freud and Adler, who both argued that personality/neurosis emerges from a singular psychic complex throughout life (Oedipus and inferiority complex, respectively). Jung tried to argue that it was not one or the other, rather it could be either or. In fact one could oscillate between the two throughout life (Oedipus/extroverted to inferiority/introverted) as different archetypal potentials are actualized, or even overcome the dichotomy altogether (individuation). And individuation is meant to resolve another key problem in psychoanalysis, i.e. that of unending treatment, the fact that analysis of the personality/neuroses can continue forever with no way to terminate.

It's interesting to consider how modestly Jung's split from Freud started, Jung merely pointed out that his patients didn't always view him as a father, but sometimes as a god, a magician, a sorcerer, etc.

When socializing I feel some "switch of modes", when I am by myself and focusing on some task I feel grounded, a balanced feeling, my consciousness feels "laid back" in my mind. Whenever I am performing some sort of task, and suddenly a social situation arises, even if its just voice chatting over the internet or sometimes even just texting I immediately feel pulled out of my zone, consciousness moving more to "the front" of my mind. I used to have that problem, my solution is that whenever I want to talk about my own experience I pretend I'm making some story on the fly.

Imagine a person says that they have family issues and I got experience with that, I won't say "Oh, this is how it's been for me [proceeds to tell person about my own life]", I instead say "Imagine there's a little dog that [proceed to tell person about my life, but they react well because they think I'm creating a story about themselves rather than me]", and then I ask them questions about "the story". It's kind of slimy but it does make people much more open to whatever you want to say, even though it's actually the exact same thing.

>>71893191
>what about Alice do you love so darn much?
There is not a single thing that I do not love. Alice in her totality is the only girl I could ever pour the sweetest notes of my heart for. But to not escape your question I will name several things.
Her seemingly pessimistic tone, in which she can so effortlessly sneak some existential undertones, makes me think of long night walks together under the Moon during which we would discuss meaninglessness of life and how to overcome it.
I truly admire her artistic and surreal Wonderland that she was able to create inside her head, as it was the main thing that drawn me to her game. I could listen to this mad girl passionately talk about her Wonderland for hours and never have enough.
Her perseverance to march despite the terrible events that she had to go through. That mixed with her relying pretty much only on herself.
Her search for hurtful truth instead of living a life of delusion is what stops me from believing that she is real or she loves me. It would be a dishonour to what her story preaches.
Also that animal remains appear poignant to her. That she likes rabbits. That she has some interest in Greek mythology. That her dresses look fantastic.
I do not know many things about her still but every time I learn something knew about her, or hear her creator talk about her, it feels like I already know that and her image of who she truly is to me is never disrupted.
And her physical beauty is a significant part of my obsession with her too, of course. That perfect face of hers still visits my dreams and I cannot have enough of looking at her. When I see her, I want to remain faithful and loyal to her for decades. Even centuries or eternity, if that was within my power. She is always the most beautiful to me. No matter how many years pass.

To put it simply and frankly: all religions and spiritual doctrines are, for the most part, genuine insights into human psychology. Take for example the four noble truths of Buddhism:
>(1) Life is suffering.
>(2) attachment to desire causes suffering.
>(3) suffering ends with the attachment to desire.
>(4) the Eightfold Path is the path to liberation from suffering.

Spiritual enlightenment basically means to have achieved mastery and understanding over one's own consciousness, personality, and being as a whole.

>The notion of nature as a self-regulating ecosystem is what philosophers call a teleological concept: a belief that things in nature happen the way they do to achieve certain ends. To truly know a thing is to know its end. The classic example of such thinking is Aristotle's Metaphysics, which dominated European thought until the 17th century.

>The idea of nature as self-regulating ecosystem lends itself to the teleological doctrine of biocentrism, the view that there is such a thing as a health of nature that needs preserving.

>Its opposite would be to assert that events in nature are entirely random and that disturbance, not stability, is the rule. Adherents of that position would not say that the environment was either healthy or unhealthy when the dinosaurs became extinct. It clearly was unhealthy for dinosaurs, but it seems to have been healthy for the ancestors of humans.

I do take some issue with the use of the author's wording of "entirely random" (I don't necessarily believe in true randomness) but aside from that, the fact remains that the idea of "stable ecosystems" is largely a manmade construct, not an aspect of reality.

Do you know what consciousness is? Do you not feel it 24 7? I think people who dont believe in consciousness either dont know what it is, or they are unironic full on NPC zombies.

But the other question more importantly. I think robots could in theory have consciousness, or that some already do, but the current bots dont really experience anything. We didnt code in any feelings or receptors to these AIs, for chatbots it is not like talking to a human since they do not think. Chatbots dont have any lines running in the background without being unprompted. If it has consciousness, then its entire life essentially is just receiving text and spitting out the best answer, kinda like when you are in a quick conversation and you speak points without really consciously thinking about them all that much. Imagine this but the entire life is like this, with not even having breaks since when you are not being prompted, you are not active and your perception of time is fucked. And that is just chatbots, image AIs have absolutely nothing in them, no mind, no equivalent to thoughts, no joy from having the work done, nothing. Just find clusters of pixels in noise that look most like the prompt and repeat is couple of times until clear image gets created. Humans can think of basically anything and perform any task that is physically possible. We are so universal in our intelligence and we also derive joy from that. These combinations of joy, stress, fear, greed and other emotions turned us from mere beasts into beings that shape their reality to our wants, wants imperfectly created for survival in the nature. Machines have no wants, the only wants they have is learn how to do a task while they are being trained, but after that they just respond, like more sophisticated reflexes. They are smart, but also mindless, and therefore essentially soulless. And even if they have consciousness, their perception of the world lacking in meaningful feel makes it irrelevant.

>>71921223
Get some olive oil and pour it in a big pan; then once it's hot, throw in a pinch of cumin seeds. Mince one (1) large onion. Toss that in as well. Put a bit of salt to speed things up and some sugar for a sweeter glaze (optional). Stir occasionally. Add your garam masala when it begins to brown. Continue frying the onion until you start to worry it's going to burn, the turn down the heat, add some finely minced garlic and ginger, and cook it a minute longer. That's when you add in the tomatoes (chopped, canned, whatever) and turn it back up to medium-high heat. Reduce it by half, making sure to stir constantly. You're free to use some vinegar to deglaze the pan if you like at this stage. Throw in your canned chickpeas and about a cup of water, or until all the components are covered. Cover, lower the heat, and wait about five minutes. Garnish with coriander (cilantro) and serve with rice.

You can make the same recipe with potato instead of chickpeas, but you need to keep the pan covered until they're tender in that case.
